title: 114_s1999
content: The Act titled "Caribbean Oil Spill Intervention, Prevention, and Preparedness Act" defines a vessel as any watercraft or artificial contrivance used for transportation on water, including structures attached to the seabed for oil or gas exploration. It also addresses grave and imminent dangers to US waters, coastlines, and related interests. The Act allows the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates to take action in waters beyond US jurisdiction if there is a grave and imminent threat of pollution from crude oil, without liability for any resulting damage. The Secretary considers the interests of the United States in determining the threat level. The Coast Guard, when operating, must consider the impacts on coastal communities, marine resources, coastal activities, shorelines, beaches, and coastal economies. SEC. 103. INTERVENTION ACTIONS. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates is authorized to coordinate and direct actions to prevent or respond to pollution of the sea by crude oil in case of a grave threat. SEC. 104. CONSULTATION PROCEDURE. SEC. 104. CONSULTATION PROCEDURE. Before taking action under section 103, the Secretary of the department with the Coast Guard must consult with flag countries of involved vessels, notify other relevant federal departments, and consider submitted views. SEC. 105. EMERGENCY AUTHORITY. The Secretary of the department with the Coast Guard can take immediate action in extreme urgency without prior consultation. SEC. 106. REASONABLE ACTIONS; CONSIDERATIONS. SEC. 106. REASONABLE ACTIONS; CONSIDERATIONS. Any action under this Act must be proportionate to the threat and not exceed what is necessary to prevent or respond to the threat. The Secretary must consider the extent and probability of imminent damage, the likelihood of effectiveness, and the extent of potential damage. SEC. 107. PERSONAL, FLAG STATE, AND FOREIGN STATE CONSIDERATIONS. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates must avoid risk to human life, provide aid to distressed persons, and not interfere with the rights and interests of others. The Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is available for actions related to sections 102, 103, and 105 of the Act. Title II focuses on foreign oil spill prevention and preparedness, including Cuban oil pollution prevention and response. SEC. 201 of the Act focuses on Cuban oil pollution prevention and response, including developing ocean current and meteorological modeling for the Straits of Florida. It also amends the National Marine Sanctuaries Act to include negotiations with Mexico, Cuba, and the Bahamas for oil pollution prevention and protection of marine resources in the Gulf of Mexico and Straits of Florida. Section 8(a) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require bidders conducting oil or gas operations in Cuban waters to submit an oil spill response plan and evidence of sufficient resources before being granted a lease. The amendment to Section 8(a) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires bidders in Cuban waters to provide an oil spill response plan and show adequate resources before obtaining a lease. This includes financial resources for removal, response costs, and damages in case of an oil discharge that threatens the marine environment of the United States. SEC. 203 of the Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to include new sections related to coral reef conservation in the Straits of Florida. This includes the addition of a new section on international coral reef conservation. The Secretary will conduct international coral reef conservation activities in the Straits of Florida, consulting with various US stakeholders and developing a coral reef ecosystem strategy. The Secretary will develop a strategy to protect coral reef ecosystems in the Straits of Florida, identifying high-value areas for US marine resources and periodically reviewing and revising the strategy as needed. The Secretary will develop a strategy to protect coral reef ecosystems in the Straits of Florida, including summarizing existing activities, establishing goals and targets for conservation, and describing appropriate international conservation activities. SEC. 204. GULF OIL SPILL RESPONSE PLAN. The Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard must conduct an oil spill risk analysis and planning process within 180 days of this Act's enactment for oil spills in the Straits of Florida and Gulf of Mexico. This includes consulting with relevant federal agencies and ensuring all critical information and spill scenarios are covered in the response plans. The Secretary must ensure that oil spill response plans include containment methods, international standards, and a joint contingency plan with Mexico, Cuba, and the Bahamas for spills in the eastern Gulf of Mexico. The plans should detail response team logistics for each country involved. The Secretary may conduct a verification process to ensure companies drilling off the coast of Cuba meet stringent standards similar to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act.
